PAS.content: Blanchot disquiets, suspends, infringes on categorical, the self-identity of the category (accusation, judgment) > [infringes] law of identity of “is” in predication
PAS.linkedContent: Blanchot disquiets, suspends, infringes on categorical, the self-identity of the category (accusation, judgment) > [infringes] law of identity of “is” in predication

T.content: is there any ruse not belonging to reason which will prevent philosophy from borrowing its categories from logos of other, affecting itself w/out delay [see POOF p. 1]?
T.linkedContent: is there any ruse not belonging to reason which will prevent philosophy from borrowing its categories from logos of other, affecting itself w/out delay [see POOF p. 1]?

WM.content: dividing essence from proper permits the play of metaphor, doesn’t involve thing itself in play of substitutions, metaphor is mediate, abstract, medium of quasi-synonymy
WM.linkedContent: dividing essence from proper permits the play of metaphor, doesn’t involve thing itself in play of substitutions, metaphor is mediate, abstract, medium of quasi-synonymy

WM.content: antikatēgoreisthai: reciprocal substitution of two predicates related to identical concrete subject
WM.linkedContent: antikatēgoreisthai: reciprocal substitution of two predicates related to identical concrete subject

WM.content: first example of antikatēgoreisthai is grammar, i.e. what is proper to man is grammar, ability to read & write > belongs to chain of what’s proper to man: logos, phōnē sēmantikē, mimēsis, metaphora
WM.linkedContent: first example of antikatēgoreisthai is grammar, i.e. what is proper to man is grammar, ability to read & write > belongs to chain of what’s proper to man: logos, phōnē sēmantikē, mimēsis, metaphora

DPi.content: Socrates’ death: katēgoria (accusation), a theological one: he introduced new demons (hetera de daimonia kaina), daimonia sometimes gods but also lesser ones, revenants
DPi.linkedContent: Socrates’ death: katēgoria (accusation), a theological one: he introduced new demons (hetera de daimonia kaina), daimonia sometimes gods but also lesser ones, revenants

BSi.content: transcategorial—“qui transcendit omne genus”: does not belong to series or table > is bêtise a transcategorial category, a quasi-transcendental?
BSi.linkedContent: transcategorial—“qui transcendit omne genus”: does not belong to series or table > is bêtise a transcategorial category, a quasi-transcendental?

BSi.content: katēgoreuō (decry, accuse in legal proceedings) also means to attribute, to say something about something: “S is P”
BSi.linkedContent: katēgoreuō (decry, accuse in legal proceedings) also means to attribute, to say something about something: “S is P”

BSi.content: bêtise can always be mine, turns around like “category of accusation,” betraying my fault > contagion, being-with of bêtise
BSi.linkedContent: bêtise can always be mine, turns around like “category of accusation,” betraying my fault > contagion, being-with of bêtise

BSi.content: bêtise as madness of definition, “S is P,” definite articles le or la, bêtise is defining as much as defined > the category is a signature of bêtise
BSi.linkedContent: bêtise as madness of definition, “S is P,” definite articles le or la, bêtise is defining as much as defined > the category is a signature of bêtise

BSi.content: Kant’s distinction btwn conflict (Streit) & war (Krieg): an institution (3rd party) must know exactly what the accusation means [re: bêtise] for it to achieve rational status of conflict
BSi.linkedContent: Kant’s distinction btwn conflict (Streit) & war (Krieg): an institution (3rd party) must know exactly what the accusation means [re: bêtise] for it to achieve rational status of conflict

BSi.content: accusation of bête deprives the accused, like animal, of all that is proper to man (language, reason, logos, sense of death, technique, history, convention, culture, laughter, tears, work)
BSi.linkedContent: accusation of bête deprives the accused, like animal, of all that is proper to man (language, reason, logos, sense of death, technique, history, convention, culture, laughter, tears, work)

BSi.content: bêtise as ambiguous hetero- or self-accusation: I’m too good, too bête
BSi.linkedContent: bêtise as ambiguous hetero- or self-accusation: I’m too good, too bête
